data.title: Oracle Financial shares surge to a record high on Tuesday over these developments
meta_keywords: Oracle Corp stake in Oracle fin
data.meta_description: Oracle's cloud revenue rose by 25% year-on-year to $5.1 billion for the quarter that ended in February, marginally higher than Wall Street estimates of $5.06 billion.
data.text:
Oracle Global Mauritius Ltd. holds a 72.78% stake in Oracle Financial, as per the December quarter shareholding pattern.

By Hormaz Fatakia

Shares of Oracle Financial Services surged as much as 7% on Tuesday after the company's parent Oracle Corp. staged a strong rally in afterhours trading overnight.

NSE

Oracle Corp.'s shares surged 14% in extended trading after reporting a spike in bookings in its cloud computing business.

Oracle's Remaining Performance Obligations, a measure of the company's sales backlog stood at $80 billion at the end of the February quarter, significantly higher than the $59 billion expected by analysts.

The Austin-based company, known for its database software, is focused on expanding its cloud infrastructure business to compete with Amazon.com Inc., Microsoft Corp. and Alphabet Inc.’s Google.

Oracle's cloud revenue rose by 25% year-on-year to $5.1 billion for the quarter that ended in February, marginally higher than Wall Street estimates of $5.06 billion.

Total sales in the fiscal third quarter increased 7.1% to $13.3 billion, roughly in line with analysts’ estimates, according to data compiled by Bloomberg.

The management expects revenue for the current quarter, which will end in May, to grow by 5% from last year. Cloud revenue, excluding Cerner will be up 23%, according to the management, who also added that Cerner, a significant headwind to the company's revenue growth, will return to revenue growth by May 2025.

Oracle Global Mauritius Ltd. holds a 72.78% stake in Oracle Financial, as per the December quarter shareholding pattern.

Shares of Oracle Financial are currently trading 4.3% higher at ₹8,449. The stock is trading at a record high, having gained 165% over the last 12 months. India's domestic mutual funds hold close to 5% stake in Oracle Financial, while LIC holds a 3.87% stake.

(With Inputs From Agencies.)
